September 14, 1922
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
The vacation period of the office is over,
and we are all back for the fall's work.

I have just finished reading your valued letters
of August 25 and September 5, making suggestions of field
experiments in malaria control designed to advance pro-
gress in this field.

Every experiment you outline impresses me as
being well worth while, although I am not sure all of
them should be undertaken by our Board.

Where an investigation is designed to settle
scientifically a controversy between labor and capital,
or between a corporation and the public, it may be best,
for obvious reasons, to have the cost of the work paid
from the public treasury rather than by funds voted from
a Rockefeller endowment.

Mr. Rose is still away on vacation. When he
returns, we shall review your suggestions together, and

September 14, 1922
consideration will be given to including estimates for
one or more of them in our program for 1923.

Assuring you we are deeply appreciative of
your co-operation and suggestions, for those you have
made in the past, and any you may make in the future,
I am,
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, John A. Ferrell. Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
